content:
Diagnosis
	1. Metastatic cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma of right temple region with extensive bone metastases

	Date of diagnosis
	January 2024

	Treatment aim
	Palliative

	Summary of completed treatment and relevant dates

	Surgery
	15 Jan 2024 Wide local excision of right temple lesion
	Histology confirmed poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with perineural invasion

	Systemic therapy
	1 Feb 2024 - 15 Apr 2024: Pembrolizumab monotherapy

	Radiotherapy
	20 Mar 2024: Palliative radiotherapy to T7 vertebral metastasis (20Gy in 5#)

	Clinical studies
	None

	Current disease status
	Progressive disease with new symptomatic bone metastases

	Current issues
	1. Severe bone pain
	2. Deteriorating mobility
	3. Increasing fatigue
	4. Weight loss

	Summary of consultation
	This 78-year-old gentleman has unfortunately shown clear evidence of disease progression despite 3 cycles of pembrolizumab. CT imaging performed yesterday demonstrates multiple new bone metastases including a concerning lesion at C5 with early cord compression, as well as progression in previously identified lesions. His performance status has declined from 1 to 3, now spending most of the day in bed due to pain and fatigue. He has lost 8kg in the past 6 weeks despite dietetic support.

He requires increasing doses of opioid analgesia, currently on oxycodone MR 40mg BD with breakthrough oxycodone liquid 5mg/5ml used 4-6 times daily. He is experiencing significant side effects from the opioids including constipation and drowsiness.

On examination today, there is tenderness over multiple thoracic vertebrae and the left hip. Neurological examination shows reduced power (4/5) in the left leg but normal sensation and reflexes. The right temple surgical site shows no evidence of local recurrence.

	Further investigations
	1. Urgent MRI whole spine
	2. Bone profile and vitamin D level
	3. DEXA scan

	Medication prescribed
	1. Increased oxycodone MR to 60mg BD
	2. Added pregabalin 75mg BD for neuropathic pain
	3. Dexamethasone 8mg OD with PPI cover

	Follow up
	1. Urgent referral to acute oncology service
	2. Referral to palliative care team
	3. Clinical review in 1 week

	Required GP actions
	1. Please monitor renal function weekly
	2. District nurse referral for support with medication administration

	Summary of information given to patient
	Detailed discussion held with patient and family regarding disease progression. Treatment with pembrolizumab will be discontinued. Focus now on symptom control and quality of life. Palliative care involvement explained and accepted.

primary_cancer.metastases: extensive bone metastases including T7 and C5 vertebrae with early cord compression
primary_cancer.histopathology_status: poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with perineural invasion

cancer_timeline.value: Wide local excision of right temple lesion
Palliative radiotherapy to T7 vertebral metastasis (20Gy in 5#)
CT shows multiple new bone metastases including C5 lesion with early cord compression
Discontinuing pembrolizumab due to disease progression

patient_facts.value: Performance status deteriorated from 1 to 3, spending most of day in bed
Severe bone pain requiring increasing opioid analgesia
Significant opioid side effects including constipation and drowsiness
Tenderness over multiple thoracic vertebrae and left hip, reduced power (4/5) in left leg
8kg weight loss in past 6 weeks despite dietetic support

status_updates.value: Metastatic cutaneous SCC showing rapid progression with new symptomatic bone metastases despite pembrolizumab. Significant decline in performance status with increasing pain and mobility issues.
Progressive disease after 3 cycles of pembrolizumab with multiple new bone metastases
Discontinuing pembrolizumab, increasing oxycodone MR to 60mg BD, adding pregabalin and dexamethasone
Significant deterioration in mobility and independence, now largely bed-bound
Urgent MRI whole spine, bone profile, vitamin D level, and DEXA scan
Urgent referral to acute oncology and palliative care teams, clinical review in 1 week
